captions.text:
Captions by www.SubPLY.com
. . . . . . . . . . . . .
Turning to entertainment,

Star Trek fans are
decrying the latest film
in the long running series,

as a fun and watchable,
action packed, thrill-ride.
Yes, it was exciting.

But where was the heavy-handed
message about tolerance,
where was the stiff acting?

I mean it just didn't seem like
a Star Trek movie to me.

I'm just really, really, disappointed
that this storyline made sense.

If I wanted to see young,
attractive people,

doing cool exiting things
I'd go watch sports.

And, with us now to 
discuss the backlash

is entertainment reporter
Bree Lindsay. -- Hi Glen.

Bree, is this Star Trek
as riveting as the fans
are complaining it is?

Oh, Glen, early reviewers 
are calling it a delightful

action-adventure movie,
and a sure-fire hit.

No wonder the fans 
feel betrayed here.

Apparently there isn't even 
 one scene set at a long table

in which interstellar diplomacy
is debated in endless detail.

Really?  I understand 
fans were angry that the

the Klingon's dialog was subtitled,
because it allows the Klingon's

to be understood by people
who haven't studied
the imaginary language for years.

Yes, but most fans were more
upset by the look of the movie.

Heart-stopping chases, 
state-of-the-art CGI,

and alien battle scenes that don't
just look like two, out of shape guys,

in bad make up 
fighting awkwardly.

That's a real slap in the face
for Trek fans.

Right, yes. But I think that 
the bigger issue is that

fans felt like Star Trek 
belonged to them,

and now the studio has 
turned it into something

that people
will actually like.

What about the casting of up-and-coming
young actor Chris Pine
as James T. Kirk,

instead of the aging, 
bloated, William Shatner?

Of course that announcement
was a huge disappointment
for fans, and Shatner, alike.

A lot of the fans have been 
saying that this movie

sullies the vision of someone 
called Gene Roddenberry.

Yes, Gene Roddenberry was 
 the hack who created the

Star Trek television show 
way back in the 40's or something.

So, is Paramount doing anything
to combat all this negative press Bree?

Yes, they are. They announced
the DVD release will feature

a special cut, 
just for the Star Trek fans,

with three hours of extra footage
in which characters stand around

debating the merits of saving
the Andorian Ambassador

from the surface of Calyx 4
until you just wish everyone was dead.

Well, that should be 
some consolation.

-- Thanks Bree.
-- Thanks Glen.

Earlier today, paramount released
this statement to ease fans concerns,

"We stand behind this film,
and firmly believe that in a few years

it will seem just as dated and
 cornball as previous Star Trek films."

Moving on now, an elderly
black woman is still following

President Obama around
and shedding a single tear
whenever he does anything.
Still Ahead:

dozens of millionaires feared dead
in Scandinavian ice hotel collapse.

title: Trekkies Bash New Star Trek Film As 'Fun, Watchable'

Yeah, it was an okay movie, but that's the whole problem. It didn't feel 
much like Trek. Does anyone even remember what the movies were about? They 
seem pretty forgettable, unlike, say, "KHAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAN!". Eh, 
but whatever. It's not like it's worse than the crap Next Generation threw 
up on the big screen before they finally closed that particular chapter.﻿

comments.author: largelysubatomic

comments.text:
I'm a trekkie, and I understand why some other trekkies hate this movie. 
It's shallow and a sensory overload of special effects etc. But we live in 
the year of 2014 now, where hollywood like most other industries make the 
largest profits from quantity production and not quality production, and 
making it an "star trek"-moive is them just using recogniztion marketing to 
make even more money.

Even though this developement is somehow sad, it's still fascinating, and 
makes one think how the production of cinema will evolve further (this is 
happening in the music industry aswell btw).

So to all my fellow trekkies affected... see this movie for what it really 
is... "Avatar 13: The mindless journey continues" ;)﻿
comments.author: Dampsvenne

comments.text:

make it Trek!

and millions of dollars with his rebooted version. You can hate it but the 
results and positive reviews speaks for themselves. Even the Disney execs

comments.text:
That J.J. Abrams' work is simple-minded and without substance or depth is 
not opinion, it is a fact. The comparative basis substantiating this fact 
is the past 50 years of Star Trek History. The films, as well as Abrams 
himself, are both agents and victims of a decaying cultural landscape. I 
will speak out against this boldly, because being polite is less important 
than telling the truth. Deal with it.
comments.author: James Lloyd

comments.text: A weak and ironic defence of a film aimed squarely at undeveloped minds.

comments.text: Grow up.

so your calling people who have a different opinion than you "idiots"? Real

intelligence. Your nothing more than a self centered person who believes 
that your right and everyone else is wrong for having different vies. Your 
the type of person that give fans a bad rep. If you don't like it fine, you 
don't like it. But don't try to bring others down just because they like 
it. People like you sicken me.

comments.text:
In some regards it (I've only seen the first, so far) was certainly 
simplified, but it remained a very fun movie. More streamlined, really, 
than dumbed down. If that helps bring Star Trek to a wider audience, and 
means fans of older Trek (like me - raised on TNG as a little girl) don't 
have to sit through convoluted nonsense like Star Trek: Nemesis, then I'm 
all for it being "dumbed down"!
comments.author: Diamond Song

comments.text:
Yes, the Onion News Network not getting its facts completely right is a 
shocking departure from their usual commitment to journalistic accuracy. In 
fact I'd go as far as to say that this report almost seems like some kind 
of... parody of proper news reporting.
comments.author: Diamond Song

comments.text:
Dear other commentators (??) please figure out what the Onion is before

comments.text:
I'm far more of a Star Wars fan than I am a Star Trek fan. And I have to 
fight an uphill battle every day against those who bash the new & better 
films. Its easier with Trek, because at least most of the world agrees that 
the new ones are better.
comments.author: NeoSoldner

comments.text:
I don't have a TV. And wasn't Star Trek always played on TV? Did you just 
tell me to turn off Star Trek?? :D I'm a avid reader of classic novels. And 
I mean classic! Doyle, Dumas, Scott, Kipling, Dickens, etc I play a video 
game like once every three months. I find it funny that a mouth-breathing 
Trekkie is lecturing me on diet. What a joke! TOS was terrible.
comments.author: NeoSoldner

comments.text:
This perception has nothing to do with the merits of J.J.'s films, and his 
nothing to do with deficiencies in the franchise prior to his involvement. 
In fact, your perception comes from deficiencies in your own capacity to 
think and judge correctly. If you turn off your television, read some 
classic novels, and cease your intake of refined sugar, video games, 
magazines, or whatever else, eventually you will come to the realization 
that you have not been corresponding with reality properly.
comments.author: James Lloyd

comments.text:
I am not and have never been a Star Wars fan, but I have always been able 
to appreciate the artistic and ideological merit of the franchise. Because 
of this insight, I can see the way in much "modern and awesome" is only a 
veneer for what is actually contained in the newer films: vapid, 
patronizing, disappointing nonsense, albeit much less so than J.J. Abrams 
consistently gaudy trash.
comments.author: James Lloyd

comments.text:
The franchise is an affront to itself. JJ rescued it from the shithole it 
started in.
comments.author: NeoSoldner

comments.text:
Trekkies are insane like that. But then many old Star Wars fans eacted the 
same way when their franchise got modern & awesome. You can't teach old 
dogs to like watching new tricks
comments.author: NeoSoldner

comments.text:
"The action scenes are mediocre. The cast is mediocre." If that's true, at 
least that's better than fucking terrible - which is what TOS is!
comments.author: NeoSoldner

comments.text: New Trek is like Galileo. Old Trek is like the Dominican Order.
comments.author: NeoSoldner

comments.text: lol what was his comment?
comments.author: Koyaanitsqatsi

comments.text: *facepalm*
comments.author: LYKAON

comments.text:
Similar sentiments have been invoked throughout history in the course of 
persecuting figures like Copernicus, Galileo, Servetus, etc, for the 
offense it created when they substantiated their views against the 
"self-evident" truths of scripture. "Copernicus seems unfamiliar with Holy 
Scripture, since his findings contradict its principles." - The Dominican 
Order, circa 1546. It makes sense that the propensity for such regressive 
thinking would find kinship in Abrams' regressive directing style.
comments.author: James Lloyd

comments.text: I don't need to substantiate my views. The truth is evident.
comments.author: LYKAON

comments.text:
If indulging that fantasy is more satisfying than substantiating your 
views, go ahead and relish in it. How disappointing. Unsurprising, but 
still disappointing.
comments.author: James Lloyd

comments.text: As I said, I see right through you.
comments.author: Lykaon Wulf

comments.text:
There is no duplicitous campaign to distract you from my "imbecility", as 
the prerequisite of perceiving such imbecility in myself is not present. 
It's more likely that these "imbecile" remarks constitute a compensatory 
imputation, emergent from the frustration of feeling imbecilic yourself. 
The devastatingly comprehensive rhetoric I've deployed in the course of 
dismantling your incorrect views can have that effect. Personal attacks 
usually indicate a loss of confidence in one's own position.
comments.author: James Lloyd

comments.text:
Purposefully using the verbage you just provided me does not mask your 
imbecility. I can see right through you, pal.
comments.author: LYKAON

comments.text:
In actual reality, where things and events are true in spite of your 
irrational, emotionally charged opinion, the opposite of what you have 
stated is correct. Abrams' films conspicuously lack artistic, intellectual, 
and creative merit, and as such their appeal is to an audience equally 
deficient in these worthwhile traits. That is why there is such an abundant 
and diverse chorus of artistically, creatively, and intellectually 
sophisticated people chastising J.J. Abrams and his worthless films.
comments.author: James Lloyd

comments.text: Then I would say to go back to the theater and watch it again.
comments.author: LYKAON

comments.text: NOW it's the end.
comments.author: LYKAON

comments.text:
It's not self-righteous or self-absorbed if what I fucking said is true, 
which it is. You're an idiot. The only reason you're bashing the new Trek 
movies is because of said truth. You are simply an imbecile, and fail to 
see that your pathetic observation is exactly the opposite: Dislike of the 
film and deficient intelligence are the only ones related.
comments.author: LYKAON

comments.text:
How about if I think that the new one's plot made very little sense and 
that it just didn't flow well as a movie? Oh, and that Khan had no real 
motivations for being evil?
comments.author: Technodreamer

comments.text:
You're mistaken. You are, no doubt, a self-righteous and ignorant idiot who 
likes to hear himself talk. Because this is true, nothing you say should be 
taken into consideration by any means. NOW it's the end of the discussion.
comments.author: LYKAON

comments.text:
You're mistaken. J.J. Abrams' work is simple-minded and without substance 
or depth. Since intelligence is required to appreciate these qualities, 
Abrams' films appeal to those of average intelligence or below. As 
subjective enjoyment goes up, an objective assessment of the viewer's 
intelligence necessarily goes down. Because this is true, a viewer's idiocy 
is directly proportionate to their enjoyment of Abrams' work, and 
intelligence is a measure of the film's admonishment. End of discussion.
comments.author: James Lloyd
